results.title: House: after five years of living
results.brief_description: The first of a certain thread of films by Charles and Ray Eames that used still images in a very filmic way. The still camera offered a freedom and flexibility that allowed Charles and Ray to capture lyrical images of their house, its garden and its decor and to provide a lasting impression of the house during their life there. The house is a classic of post-war American architecture which the Eameses designed and built in 1949 as part of the Case Study House Program. Music composed by Elmer Bernstein. Performed by Martin Ruderman (flute), Dorothy Remsen (harp), Armand Kaproff (cello) and Elmer Bernstein (piano).

results.title: House with a secret
results.brief_description: The story of a girl who finds a wallet outside an old house and takes it inside, but the house is deserted and untidy except for one room with presents in it. She hears a bridal couple and their friends arriving and rushes down to give the wallet to them, but they brush past her. She walks sadly outside and places the wallet where she found it, but picks up the bride’s posy in return and skips away with it in her hair.

results.title: House that Jack built
results.brief_description: An information film on the operation of the Local Building Trade Apprenticeship Scheme in England. Shows high school students working as laborers at a housing project construction site as part of a work experience scheme.

results.title: House on Haunted Hill
results.creator_credit: William Castle and Allied Artists Pictures
results.brief_description: Directed in 1958 by 50s B-grade horror maestro William Castle, “House on Haunted Hill” boasted the arrival of “Emergo”, a fluorescent skeleton that swept across the head of audience members in the cinema. Widowed playboy millionaire Frederick Loren (Vincent Price) invites 5 guests: a race driver, a columnist, the previous owner, a psychiatrist, and a typist to spend a night with Loren and his fourth wife, Annabelle, in the haunted house. At the strike of midnight the doors will close, the electricity will be out, and 12 hours lie ahead in a tenement in which there have been several mysterious deaths, including those of Loren’s previous 3 wives. The 4 men and 3 women have nothing in common, other than their need for money, and Loren has posted a reward of $10,000 for anyone who lasts the night. Low in budget, the film boasts several frightening scenes, including an acid bath and dismembered head, earning the film an M rating. Cast includes: Vincent Price, Richard Long, Alan Marshal, Carolyn Craig. Music composed and conducted by Castle collaborator Von Dexter. Remade in 1999 by William Malone.

results.title: House on Haunted Hill
results.brief_description: A remake of the 1959 film of the same name. A millionaire offers a group of diverse people $1,000,000 to spend the night in a haunted house with a horrifying past.

constellations_other.name: Optical toys, Totoro and terrors
constellations_other.description: Victorian-era optical toys have inspired the biggest animation studios and the scariest horror films.

results.title: House of Wax lobby cards
results.brief_description: Reproduction movie lobby card set for the promotio of the film ‘House of Wax’ a Warner Brothers production c1953. The set contains a series of eight colour pinted cards with illustrated scenes from the movie and graphic text noting ‘Natural Vision, Color by Warner Color, 3 Dimension, House of Wax.

results.title: House of Wax
results.brief_description: House of Wax was the first colour 3D feature film that incorporated stereo sround. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening the drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio.

constellations_primary.name: Movies on wax
constellations_primary.description: Waxing lyrical about the supernatural and early 21st-century teen stars.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

results.description: In the original trailer for House of Wax (1953), Warner Brothers heralded the third dimension as “the new wonder of the entertainment world”. Though that wonder had been discovered a year earlier in Bwana Devil (1952), Warner Brothers explored immersion further by releasing a colour 3D feature that incorporated stereo sound for the first time. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening tension and drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio. Both of these innovations are standard in filmmaking today.
description_for_label: In the original trailer for House of Wax (1953), Warner Brothers heralded the third dimension as “the new wonder of the entertainment world”. Though that wonder had been discovered a year earlier in Bwana Devil (1952), Warner Brothers explored immersion further by releasing a colour 3D feature that incorporated stereo sound for the first time. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening tension and drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio. Both of these innovations are standard in filmmaking today.

results.title: House of Wax
results.brief_description: A group of unwitting teens are stranded near a strange wax museum and soon must fight to survive and keep from becoming the next exhibit.

results.title: House of wax
results.creator_credit: Andre De Toth, Bryan Foy and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Professor Henry Jarrod is a renowned wax sculptor who is plunged into madness when an arsonist burns down his wax museum. Jarrod loses his life’s work and, having lost the ability to use his flame-scarred hands, comes up with a new way of stocking his reformed House of Wax in New York. Aided by his mute assistant (Charles Bronson), he dips his victims in wax! Cast includes Vincent Price, Frank Lovejoy, Phyllis Kirk and Carolyn Jones.
